column4: I am asking again. I am wanting to connecting a Windows computer from Ubuntu. I installed RealVNC on Windows but I can't connect despite writing the IP adress and the port number of the computer. What I must do?
on a local lan? Or internet?
you have to ssh tunnle vnc that way most likely.. just straight vnc is insecure
you could do a 'live cd type install' to the flash drive.. or use the alternative installer cd   for a full  install. it asks where to put grub at the end of the install i belive
you proberly dont need to do a 'normal' type install to a flash drive

the usb-creator-tool for ubuntu can make a persistant install setup. or you can install a live setup with unetbootin and check pendrivelinux.com to see what changes to make to the syslinux.cfg to turn itinto a persistant install
only differance from a persistant setup and non-persistant is a kernel boot option, and a special file for the changes.
a persistant usb install uses fat32 for the pendrive and ext2/3 for the persistant save file..  if thats what you are asking about.
You can install the ubuntu-desktop pacakge if you want.
but its a bit of an annoyance changeing from one to the other.. its doable however.  Just not as easy as it should be
theres just some annoyanced you have to watch out for.   settings in teh UNR vs the normal desktop can cause  things to not work as well as they should
You need to use virtualbox from teh VBOX homepage not the 'free/ose' version in the repos. in order for vbox to see usb devices.

a quick read of teh virtualbox manual/pdf from their homepage expalins how to set it up to access usb devices. Ive rarely needed to do so, add the device in the config settings, then a button/menu at the bottom of the vbox window is all i rember.
you mean you want to set the DNS servers your system is using?
you could just edit  /etc/resolv.conf   , somehow i got a custome DNS entry in there in addation to my isp's
the file /etc/resolv.conf has the DNS server settings used by the system. But network manager might overwrite/change that file.
i just edited my /etc/resolv.conf by hand.. and  the change took affect. I rarely use network manager to change the stuff like that.
you may need to set it to be a static ip in network manager. i seem to recall others having to do this int he past
i notice that network manager has a 'auto DHCP - address only' setting.. that would i think let you change the dns
the user you are logged in as has sudo rights?
no idea then. I can change them here with no issues. Or i can just edit the /etc/resolv.conf if i want to change it quickly. but NM may overwrite tose changes on the next reboot.
